docs.lead_paragraph: It may seem hard to believe that a disorder first identified nearly 70 years ago that affects as many as 10 percent of women would still be unrecognized by many doctors and in most of those who have it. But that is the case with a condition called polycystic ovary syndrome, or PCOS, a bodywide metabolic disorder characterized by abnormal hormone levels that can result in distressing and sometimes life-threatening problems, including infertility, obesity, acne, excessive facial and body hair, diabetes, heart disease and uterine cancer.

headline.main: Women Can Fight an Almost Secret Syndrome

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on polycystic ovary syndrome, bodywide metabolic disorder in women characterized by abnormal hormone levels; syndrome can result in distressing and sometimes life-threatening problems; describes syndrome, its diagnosis and treatment and related emotional problems; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As many as 20,000 Americans died in accidents at home in 1998, a new survey reports, and an additional 7 million were hurt. The study was released by the Injury Prevention Research Center, part of the University of North Carolina, and was based on a review of death certificates, emergency and clinic records and earlier studies.

headline.main: Home Is Where the Harm Is

docs.abstract: Survey by University of North Carolina's Injury Prevention Research Center finds that as many as 20,000 Americans died in accidents at home in 1998 and additional 7 million were injured; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: As many as 20,000 Americans died in accidents at home in 1998, a new survey reports, and an additional 7 million were hurt.    The study was released by the Injury Prevention Research Center, part of the University of North Carolina, and was based on...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some advocates of loosening laws against selling kidneys for transplants describe such agreements as winning arrangements. Some people improve their economic standings with few risks to their health. The others receive organs that can mean the difference between life and death. But a new study in The Journal of the American Medical Association paints a much darker picture of the organ-sale business, at least in India. Indians who sold kidneys, in violation of Indian law, ended up no better off financially in the long run, the study said. And many reported health problems that they attributed to the surgery.

headline.main: VITAL SIGNS: Rx MONEY; When People Sell Their Kidneys

docs.abstract: Study led by Dr Madhav Goyal of Geisinger Health System in State College, Pa, published in Journal of American Medical Assn, finds that desperately poor people of Chennai, India, who sold their kidneys ended up no better off financially; finds many reported health problems attributed to surgery (M)
docs.snippet: Some advocates of loosening laws against selling kidneys for transplants describe such agreements as winning arrangements. Some people improve their economic standings with few risks to their health. The others receive organs that can mean the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Jealousy, according to evolutionary psychologists, evolved a million or so years ago on the African plain, where life was no picnic. Out there on the savanna, a man had to constantly guard against cuckoldry, lest he squander his resources, unwittingly feeding that hard-earned leg of mastodon to some other guy's progeny.

headline.main: Jealous? Maybe It's Genetic. Maybe Not.

docs.abstract: Article on long-standing nature versus nurture debate over what triggers jealousy in men and women; research led by Northeastern University psychologist Dr David DeSteno, in report in November issue of the Journal of Pesonality and Social Psychology, asserts that sex difference revealed in studies by evolutionary psychologists is spurious; postulates that jealousy could have evolved in each sex for reasons other than survival pressures that evolved in early humankind; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past decade, fertility experts have made major advances in reproductive technology. They have learned how to inject a single microscopic sperm into an egg to ensure fertilization; they can retrieve an egg from one woman, fertilize it and implant it into another's uterus; and they have succeeded in freezing a young woman's eggs so she could have access to them later in life when she is ready to reproduce. But increasingly these experts are finding that they must pay attention to the most fundamental and low-tech of issues, the emotional health of their infertility patients.

headline.main: Fertility Clinics Begin to Address Mental Health

docs.abstract: Article on new focus by many infertility centers in US on emotional health of their patients; about half of 370 centers approved by Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology have hired psychologists and started support groups and stress-reduction workshops in past two years; photo; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Common Thread: Mothers, Daughters and the Power of Empathy,'' by Dr. Martha Manning, William Morrow/HarperCollins, $39.50. Why, the psychologist-author of this thoughtful book asks, do we spend hours thinking about our mothers and daughters? Her answer: ''Because it's the longest-running show in town and we've had front-row seats for our entire lives. Some of us got our tickets for free, and others paid dearly for them.''
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book The Common Thread: Mothers, Daughters and the Power of Empathy by Dr Martha Manning; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Providing information about an outbreak of communicable diseases -- quickly, candidly and in plain language -- is essential in gaining public trust, and in a public health emergency it can be a matter of life and death. Accurate communication can be as important as the medical detective and laboratory work in preventing the spread of the disease because it prevents misinformation and rumors that can undermine confidence and produce panic in any outbreak.

headline.main: At the Health Department, the Messengers Still Stumble

docs.abstract: Article on communication problems that continue to plague Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; Dr Julie L Gerberding, new director of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, played down importance of recent briefing on smallpox while officials at briefing, in major change from previous policy, said they would recommend that smallpox vaccination eventually be made available to all Americans who want it; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For 15 years, my father and stepmother enjoyed their life together immensely. They traveled to Europe and gambled in Atlantic City. They drank and bickered and smoked together and doted together on their two grandchildren, whom they adored. But then, in the summer of 2001, my father learned he had pancreatic cancer. A couple of months later, his wife, Sally, received her own diagnosis, esophageal cancer. He was 71; she 10 years younger.
docs.abstract: David Tuller Cases column, exploring concept of spouses dying together, offers case of his father and stepmother, who were diagnosed months apart with cancer, refused chemotherapy and died two days apart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent balmy evening, Dr. Joseph LeDoux, a professor of neuroscience at New York University, strode to the stage of the Cornelia Street Cafe in Greenwich Village and read from his latest book, ''The Synaptic Self: How Our Brains Become Who We Are.'' Astonishingly, the audience -- graduate students, publishing executives and scientists --greeted Dr. LeDoux's performance with enthusiasm usually reserved for rock stars.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/Joseph LeDoux; Taking a Clinical Look at Human Emotions

docs.abstract: Excerpts from conversation with New York University neuroscientist Dr Joseph LeDoux; LeDoux, who has been major force in changing approaches to human brain research, has been finding ways to study how brain processes emotions; he comments on his latest book, The Synaptic Self: How Our Brains Become Who We Are; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Drugs known as clot-busters have the potential to save the lives of untold people brought to emergency rooms after suffering strokes. But many doctors continue to use the drugs incorrectly, often with serious consequences, a new study reports. Researchers from Yale found that over two years at 16 hospitals in Connecticut, mistakes were made in the way the drugs were given to 97 percent of the stroke victims studied. Some of the mistakes were inconsequential, the researchers reported in The Archives of Internal Medicine, but many were not.
docs.abstract: Yale University research team led by Dr Dawn Bratava, reporting in Archives of Internal Medicine, finds that many doctors continue to use clot-busting drugs incorrectly in patients suffering ischemic strokes; concludes that thrombolytic drugs are safe when properly used and urge better doctor education; drawing (M)
